awd_titl_txt: Meeting: BIO-IOS Enabling Discovery through Genomic Tools (EDGE) Program's Awardee Meeting to be held 29 April 2019 in Alexandria (VA)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Enabling Discovery through Genomic Tools (EDGE) program was established in 2016 to provide tools, approaches and associated infrastructure that are critically needed to directly test gene function in diverse non-canonical model organisms.  Funds are provided to support the participation of the scientific leaders and key personnel of currently funded EDGE projects in a one-day EDGE awardee meeting to be held on April 29, 2019 in Alexandria, VA. This inaugural meeting offers opportunities for EDGE project personnel to network and discuss the progress, pitfalls and long-term scientific and societal implications of these important resource development projects. In addition, participants will learn about and discuss novel strategies and best practices related to rapid and efficient dissemination of resources and knowledge gained from their respective projects. As all these projects have the common theme of potentially catalyzing larger communities of investigators with new techniques, this meeting will also provide an opportunity for participants to discuss how best to engage with and communicate project outcomes between research communities and to a broader public audience. It is the hope that this meeting will initiate a long-term dialog about the consequences of the use of novel techniques in non-canonical model systems, both for greater scientific insight as well as potential broader impacts for society.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The funded grant supported a conference that brought together 21 research teams that were supported by the National Science Foundation's IOS-EDGE program. This program seeks to foster advances in genetic technology to conduct experimental genetic analyses of understudied organisms. The conference (held at NSF in 2019) allowed researchers studying 21 different groups of organisms, to exchange information on their progress and insights. This provided a networking opportunity for faculty who seek related genetic tools, but otherwise work on very different biological fields and different organisms. And, the conference provided an opportunity for students and postdoctoral researchers to network with members of other research teams from across the nation. This conference served to promote communication and collaboration in developing new genetic research tools. Subsequently, the funding was also used to support IOS-EDGE funded researchers communicating their progress to the broader genetics community, through a symposium at the Plant and Animal Genome conference in early 2020.  The outcome of this grant is a network of collaborations between research teams pursuing shared interests in experimental genetics, and improved communication of these experimental genetic innovations to a broader audience of researchers, so that they may themselves implement these new tools. The program supported dissemination of new research tools through conference, lectures, and the creation of instructional videos showing how to conduct specific laboratory research protocols.
